publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: Hay any worke for Cooper: or a briefe pistle directed by waye of an hublication to the reverende byshopps : counselling them, if they will needs be barrelled vp, for feare of smelling in the nostrels of her Maiestie [and] the state, that they would vse the aduise of reuerend Martin, for the prouiding of their cooper. Because the reuerend T.C. (by which misticall letters, is vnderstood, eyther the bounsing parson of Eastmeane, or Tom Coakes his chaplaine) to bee an vnskilfull and a beceytfull [sic] tubtrimmer. Wherein worthy Martin quits himselfe like a man I warrant you, in the modest defence of his selfe and his learned pistles, and makes the coopers hoopes to flye off, and the Bishops tubs to leake out of all crye. Penned and compiled by Martin the Metropolitane
monogr.author: Marprelate, Martin

div.head: Falts escaped
div.p: Tytle line ten / read / Chaplaine hath shewed himselfe in his late Admonition as the people of England to be / &c. Epistle page third / read Eulogein for Eulogeni. Beare with the rest of the falts.
